--- Johannes Link <john.link@...> wrote:
> > Have other folks used this approach, or something similar?  What do
> you
> > all think of this approach to the problem?
> 
> My concern is twofold:
> a) You bring testing logic into your production code. It's reasonable
> to change your design to make it more testable but weaving testing
> *logic* into production code feels strange to me.

A good point.  What do you think about the comment at the end, whereby
the factory would have only three static methods:

public Factory getInstance();
protected void setOverrideFactory(Factory testFactory);
protected void clearOverrideFactory();

This should limit the test specific code to the getInstance method,
which would then look something like:

public Factory getInstance() {
    if (overrideFactory!=null) {
        return overrideFactory
    } else {
        //do the usual thing
    }
}

This would also allow classes to make their own MockFactories for
whatever they need.

> b) Having more than just one or two of those static factories raises
> chances to forget about initializing all override values in setUp and
> clearing them again in tearDown.

I agree, a "code smell" is too many factories.  Two or three is a good
threshold number, I think.

Kevin
